data_vis module¶

Created on Fri Jan 19 13:53:57 2018

@author: eddr

This module contains code to create Bokeh visualisations in python from the traffic flow and GDP data.

data_vis.create_sources(df, traffic_feature, nuts_level, region_name, gdp_feature=['GDP Growth', 'gdp'], nuts_col='area_level', region_col='area_name')[source]¶

Creates sources for the joint_plot

Parameters:
  • df (DataFrame) – data for the joint plot
  • nuts_level (string) – heirarcical level for the region to create the jointplot for
  • region_name (string) – name of the region to create the jointplot for
  • gdp_feature (List) – columns in df containing gdp data
  • nuts_col (string) – column in df containing the nuts level for the region
  • region_col (string) – column in df containing the region name for the data to plot
returns source_list (List): data for joint_plot. Contains three
ColumnDataSource objects. The first two contain the data for the pdf plots on the x and y axis. The third contains the data for the scatter plot.
data_vis.cross_correlation_charts(df, data_cols, key_names, colour={3: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c'], 4: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728'], 5: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd'], 6: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b'], 7: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b', '#e377c2'], 8: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b', '#e377c2', '#7f7f7f'], 9: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b', '#e377c2', '#7f7f7f', '#bcbd22'], 10: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b', '#e377c2', '#7f7f7f', '#bcbd22', '#17becf']}, corr_col='gdp_growth', x_label='Lag (years)', y_label='Signal overlap', tb_loc='right', plot_x=1000, plot_y=400, lag_line_col='black', lag_line_alpha=0.75, lag_line_dash='dashed')[source]¶

Creates a tabbed bokeh plot with multiple data series’ cross correlation function with a single other series with a line and label on the chart that gives the lag with the highest signal overlap.

Parameters:
  • df (DataFrame) – contains data to plot
  • data_cols (list) – columns in src containing data to plot, if not passed, it plots all columns
  • key_names (List) – more readable names for data_cols, if not passed data_cols is used
  • x_label (string) – x axis label
  • y_label (string) – y axis label
  • cor_col (string) – column in df containing data series to cross correlate with data columns in data_col
  • colours (Palette) – Colour palette to use when plotting
  • lag_line_col (string) – Colour for the line indicating lag with max overlap
  • lag_line_alpha (numeric) – alpha (transparency) of the lag line
  • tb_loc (sting) – tool bar location
  • lag_line_dash (string) – Dash pattern for the line indicating lag with max overlap see: https://bokeh.pydata.org/en/latest/docs/user_guide/styling.html#line-properties
  • plot_x (numeric) – plot width in pixes on screen
  • plot_y (numeric) – plot height in pixes on screen
Returns:

Widget containing the plotted charts
Return type:

(bokeh Tabs)
data_vis.frange(start, stop, step)[source]¶

generator that starts at a number, increase by an increment until the number it yields exceeds a limit

Parameters:
  • start (numeric) – The number we start at
  • stop (numeric) – Stop yeilding when we exceed this
  • step (numeric) – The increment
data_vis.get_pdf(data)[source]¶

Compute the pdf of a data series

Parameters:data (DataFrame) –
Returns:The probablity density function kde.support (array): for plotting
Return type:pdf (array)
data_vis.joint_plot(source_lst, x_feature, y_feature, x_label, y_label, plot_size=(800, 600), size_ratio=0.85, fit_line=True, logo=None, toolbar=None)[source]¶

Creates a scatter plot to be show with probablity density function plots in the joint_plot function

Parameters:
  • source_list (List) – contains three ColumnDataSource object, the first two are for the x and y pdf chart respectively, the third is for the scatter plot.
  • x_feature (string) – the feature in src to plot on the x axis
  • y_feature (string) – the feature in src to plot on the y axis
  • x_label (string) – Label for the x axis
  • y_label (string) – Label for the y axis
  • plot_size (List like) – width and height of the plot
  • plot_ratio (numeric) – Relative size of scatter plot, larger the value the bigger the scatter plot relative to the pdf plots. Values between 0 - 1.
  • fit_line (bool) – Plot a linear least squares line of best fit
  • logo (bool) – Display the Bokeh logo or not
  • toolbar (bool) –
Returns:

Bokeh GridPlot object with the scatter and

pdf plots within it.
Return type:

joint_plot (Gridplot)
data_vis.lag_gdp(df, lag, year_col='year_label', gdp_cols=['GDP Growth', 'gdp'], area_cols=['area_name', 'area_level'])[source]¶

Lags the gdp data year

Parameters:
  • df (DataFrame) – Contains the gdp and traffic data
  • lag (numeric) – how many years to lag the gdp data
  • year_col (string) – Column in df containing the year
  • gdp_cols (List) – Columns in df containing gdp data
  • area_cols (List) – Columns in df contain geographic data
returns (DataFrame): contains data with traffic values matched to lagged
gdp data
data_vis.lin_reg_line(source, x_feature, y_feature)[source]¶

Creates a linear regression line for plot_scatter

Parameters:
  • source (ColumnDataSource) – Contains the data to fit
  • x_feature – feature on the x axis (IV)
  • y_feature – feature on the y axis (DV)
returns: line_src (ColumnDataSource) contains fit, the fitted line
(predicted y values), +_err and -_err the + and - one standard error lines and x_vals, the x value for each fitted value in fit
data_vis.multiline_plot(src, key_names, title, x_label, y_label, x_feature, data_cols=None, colours={3: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c'], 4: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728'], 5: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd'], 6: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b'], 7: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b', '#e377c2'], 8: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b', '#e377c2', '#7f7f7f'], 9: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b', '#e377c2', '#7f7f7f', '#bcbd22'], 10: ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c', '#d62728', '#9467bd', '#8c564b', '#e377c2', '#7f7f7f', '#bcbd22', '#17becf']}, bold_col='red', bold_thick=1.5, bold_feature='gdp_growth', alpha=0.75, tb_loc='above', plot_width=1000, plot_height=750, leg_loc='bottom_right', font_size='8pt', messages=True)[source]¶

Creates a bokeh plot with multiple data series’ plotted as a line. One of these data series can be selected to be of a particular colour and thickness, useful for highlighting one particular data series. It is also possible to show/hide particular series by clicking on its entry in the legend

Parameters:
  • src (ColumnDataSource) – contains data to plot
  • data_cols (list) – columns in src containing data to plot, if not passed, it plots all columns
  • title (string) – Title of the plot
  • x_label (string) – x axis label
  • y_label (string) – y axis label
  • x_feature (string) – column containing the year the data corrisponds to
  • data_cols – the columns containing data to plot
  • colours (Palette) – Colour palette to use when plotting
  • bold_col (string) – Colour for the highligted data series
  • bold_thick (numeric) – Line thickness for the highlighted data series
  • "string" (bold_feature) – name of the column in src containing data to highlight
  • alpha (numeric) – alpha (transparency) of the plotted lines
  • tb_loc (sting) – tool bar location see: https://bokeh.pydata.org/en/latest/docs/user_guide/tools.html
  • plot_width (numeric) – plot size
  • plot_height (numeric) – plot size
  • leg_loc ("string") – location of the legend see: https://bokeh.pydata.org/en/latest/docs/user_guide/styling.html#legends
  • font_size (string) – size of font of the axis label text
Returns:

the figure created
Return type:

plot (bokeh figure)
data_vis.pdf_plot(src, feature, plot=None, x_suffix='_support', y_suffix='_density', plot_size=(600, 150), axis_swap=False, logo=None, toolbar=None)[source]¶

Creates a probablity density plot to be show with a scatter plot in the joint_plot function

Parameters:
  • src (ColumnDataSource) – we create the plot from the data here
  • feature (string) – the feature in src to plot
  • plot (Figure) – bokeh figure to create the plot with, will create our own if this is None.
  • x_suffix (string) – suffix to append to feature to indicate the column in src of the values to plot on the x axis
  • x_suffix – suffix to append to feature to indicate the column in src of the values to plot on the x axis
  • plot_size (List like) – width and height of the plot
  • axis_swap (bool) – When set to True, swap the axes, so x becomes y and y becomes x
  • logo (bool) – Display the Bokeh logo or not
  • toolbar (bool) –
Returns:

Bokeh Figure of the pdf for the feature indicated by

feature in the source data, src
Return type:

plot (Figure)
data_vis.plot_scatter(src, x_feature, y_feature, x_label, y_label, plot=None, plot_size=(600, 450), fit_line=False, fit_line_col='black', logo=None, toolbar=None)[source]¶

scatter_plot

Creates a scatter plot to be show with probablity density function plots in the joint_plot function

Parameters:
  • src (ColumnDataSource) – we create the plot from the data here
  • y_feature (string) – the feature in src to plot on the x axis
  • y_feature – the feature in src to plot on the y axis
  • x_label (string) – Label for the x axis
  • y_label (string) – Label for the y axis
  • plot (Figure) – bokeh figure to create the plot with, will create our own if this is None.
  • plot_size (List like) – width and height of the plot
  • fit_line (bool) – Plot a linear least squares line of best fit
  • fit_line_col – (string): colour of the line of best fit,
  • logo (bool) – Display the Bokeh logo or not
  • toolbar (bool) –
Returns:

Bokeh Figure showing a scatter plot for two features

in the source data, src
Return type:

plot (Figure)
